text: Military Oahu Star
label: BODY

text: DoD Looks To Help Disabled Veterans
label: HH1

text: Donna Miles
label: BODY

text: American Forces Press Service
label: BODY

text: WASHINGTON – Veterans with service-related disabilities looking for business opportunities need look no
label: BODY

text: further than the U.S. government – a more specifically, the Defense Department.
label: BODY

text: DoD, the federal government’s biggest buyer of goods and services, is working to dramatically boost the
label: BODY

text: contracts it awards to small businesses owned by service-disabled veterans, according to the defense
label: BODY

text: secretary’s chief advocate for small business affairs.
label: BODY

text: DoD currently awards about $500 million in contracts every year to businesses owned and operated by
label: BODY

text: veterans with service-related disabilities.  Frank Ramos said today during an interview with the Pentagon
label: BODY

text: Channel and the American Forces Press Service.  But the goal is to increase that amount more than
label: BODY

text: tenfold – to $6 billion – within the next five years, Ramos said.
label: BODY

text: That would bring the Defense Department in line with a law that requires all federal agencies to award at
label: BODY

text: least 3 percent of their procurement dollars to small business owned and operated by service-disabled
label: BODY

text: veterans.  President Bush issued a presidential executive order last October requiring all agencies to
label: BODY

text: develop a strategic plan to put the legislation into effect.
label: BODY

text: Boosting contracting opportunities for service-disabled veterans reflects the nation’s recognition of their
label: BODY

text: service and sacrifices, Ramos said.
label: BODY

text: It benefits the Defense Department, as well, by tapping into the expertise veterans with hands-on
label: BODY

text: experience with the latest military equipment and systems and an understanding of the military’s needs.
label: BODY

text: “There’s a tremendous training ground in experience base that they bring to the table,” Ramos said.
label: BODY

text: In addition, many of these veterans already possess the security clearances required to bid on some
label: BODY

text: military contracts, he said.
label: BODY

text: To help get the word out to service-disabled opportunities with the Defense Department, the DoD Office
label: BODY

text: of Small and Disadvantaged Business Utilization is conducting an extensive outreach and education
label: BODY

text: program.
label: BODY

text: They’ve teamed up with the Small Business Administration and launched a Website to help educate
label: BODY

text: service-disabled veteran-owned businesses about government contracting and subcontracting
label: BODY

text: opportunities.  In addition, they’re encouraging business owners to join the Central Contractor Registry,
label: BODY

text: used to award DoD contracts and subcontracts.
label: BODY

text: Service-disabled veterans – particularly those new to the business community or thinking of starting their
label: BODY

text: own businesses – “need to understand what the processes and requirements are” when contracting or
label: BODY

text: subcontracting with the federal government, Ramos said.
label: BODY

text: The first National Veterans Small Business Conference, in June, helped get the word out about business
label: BODY

text: opportunities in DoD to more than 700 attendees.  Most of them were service-disabled veterans who
label: BODY

text: owned small businesses.
label: BODY

text: While emphasizing DoD’s interest in awarding more contracts to service-disabled veterans, Ramos
label: BODY

text: stressed that “that there’s no guarantee that just because you’re a disabled veteran, that you’ll get a
label: BODY

text: contract.”
label: BODY

text: Whether they’re bidding on a contract to build a roadway, refurbish a building, provide computer
label: BODY

text: consulting or deliver another service or product, they have to be able to meet a specific need in a
label: BODY

text: professional manner, Ramos said.  “You must bring forward a solution and some competency to it,” he
label: BODY

text: said.  “Whatever you produce for the department must be the best.  There is no room for mediocrity.”
label: BODY

text: That standard is critical, because America’s warfighters rely on the products and services contractors
label: BODY

text: deliver to be the department.  “And if it fails, it could be catastrophic,” Ramos said.  “So we want the best
label: BODY

text: of the best.”
label: BODY

text: Ramos encourages service-disabled veterans interested in contracting with the Defense Department to
label: BODY

text: evaluate the department’s needs and come forward with concrete ways to meet them.  “They need to
label: BODY

text: come in and say, “What solutions can I provide the Department of Defense?  What can I bring to the
label: BODY

text: table?”  Ramos said.
label: BODY

text: For those interested in sharing their skills and expertise, Ramos predicts big opportunities ahead.
label: BODY

text: More information is posted on the Small Business Administration and DoD Office of Small and
label: BODY

text: Disadvantaged Business Utilization Websites.
label: BODY
